docs.title: Julian G.
docs.text: Technologist. Fabricator. Freediver.

docs.title: Welcome to the ApneaScrap Lab Blog
docs.text:
We're starting a blog to share progress on DIY freediving gear and testing. Stay tuned for updates.

This space will host:

  • Research notes that capture experiments and the theory behind our DIY projects.
  • Updates on builds, repairs, and anything else happening in the lab.
  • Brainstorming sessions where we think through solutions to tricky problems.
  • Field tests as we take prototypes into the water and report what worked (and what didn't).

docs.title: Research Notes: Foot Pockets for a Short Carbon Training Fin
docs.text:
I want to build a short carbon bifin for pool and training. Before cutting any carbon, I need to choose the foot pocket. These notes collect what I’ve learned so far.

The main questions:

  1. Which pockets are most commonly used, and why?
  2. Which ones fit DIY blades without heavy mods?
  3. How much do blade angle and rails matter for short fins?
  4. Where can I find solid references?

docs.title: 1. Popular models
docs.text:
• C4 – lightweight, multiple stiffness options
  • Pathos – 33° angle, minimal rubber for direct power transfer
  • CETMA S-WiNG – ultralight, no side rails
  • Leaderfins Classic – integrated rails
  • SEAC – comfort-oriented
  • Mares Razor / Omer Stingray – widely available, classic rubber pockets

docs.title: 2. DIY blade compatibility
docs.text:
These freediving foot pockets are known to accept third-party or home-made blades:

  • Cetma Composites S-WiNG
  • Mares Razor
  • Pathos
  • Capt. Nemo
  • Sporasub
  • OMER Stingray
  • UltraFins

docs.title: 3. Angle considerations
docs.text:
• Blade angle usually between 20°–33°.
  • Larger angles favor surface swimming and gliding, but reduce blade snap.
  • Smaller angles (or flat pockets) suit continuous kicking, often better for short fins.

docs.title: 4. Rail considerations
docs.text:
• Rails stiffen the blade and channel water.
  • Long, thick rails can dampen flex and reduce reactivity — especially noticeable on shorter blades.
  • Finding: small rails at the foot pocket let the carbon blade flex and generate thrust more effectively.

docs.title: 5. References
docs.text:
• C4 guide to pockets and blades (PDF)
  • Leaderfins foot pockets
  • UltraFins foot pockets

docs.title: Research Notes: Monofin Foot Pockets
docs.text:
This is the second half of my research — this time looking at monofin foot pockets. Most DIY monofins seem to either use dedicated monofin pockets or just adapt bifin pockets. I want to collect the options here to see which direction makes sense for a DIY build.

The main problems I need to solve are: 1. What dedicated monofin pockets exist 2. How bifin pockets get adapted for monofins 3. Which options make sense for training vs. performance

docs.title: Dedicated Monofin Foot Pockets
docs.text:
A couple of manufacturers make pockets specifically for monofins:

  • Waterway Monofin Pockets Flat (not angled) design. Old-school style, simple and sturdy.

  • CETMA Modular Monofin Uses a modular system so blades can be swapped. Also not angled.

Both are purpose-built for monofins, but the lack of angle might make them feel stiffer and less ergonomic compared to Pathos-style bifin pockets.

docs.title: Adapted Bifin Pockets for Monofins
docs.text:
It turns out a lot of commercial monofins just adapt bifin foot pockets:

  • Waterway Nemo Wing Monofin – looks like standard bifin pockets mounted onto a monofin blade.
  • Oceaner Carbon Monofin – same idea, bifin-style pockets glued/attached to a wide blade.

This approach is appealing for DIY because bifin pockets are easier to source, and I can choose comfort/angle (Pathos, SEAC, Leaderfins, etc.) based on preference.

docs.title: Training Monofins
docs.text:
For pool work and technique training, there are monofins built specifically for fast tempo kicking:

  • Finis Evo Monofin – small blade, very quick response, designed for swimming drills.

Not a traditional freediving monofin, but worth noting as inspiration for a short, snappy training blade.

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• Waterway monofin pockets
  • CETMA modular monofin system
  • Waterway Nemo Wing monofin
  • Oceaner Carbon Monofin
  • Finis Evo training monofin

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
Right now I see two directions:

  • Dedicated monofin pockets (Waterway, CETMA) → simple but not angled, less ergonomic.
  • Bifin pockets adapted to monofins (Waterway Nemo Wing, Oceaner) → more flexibility, and I can pick pockets I already like (Pathos, SEAC, Leaderfins).

For DIY, the adapted bifin pocket route looks way easier and gives me more control over comfort and angle. That might be the smarter first step before I experiment with dedicated monofin pockets.

docs.title: Research Notes: DIY Carbon Bifin BOM
docs.text:
Now that I’ve mapped out the foot pockets, I want to gather everything I need for actually building a short carbon bifin blade. This is basically my BOM (bill of materials) plus a few notes on layering and finishing.

The problems I need to solve here are: 1. Which carbon fabrics and resin to use 2. How to prepare and laminate properly 3. What to use as a support base 4. How many layers are typical for bifins 5. How to finish the blades with rails and glue

docs.title: Core Materials
docs.text:
Carbon cloths (from Easy Composites): - 210 g 3k plain weave - 200 g 3k plain weave (same as above) - 200 g 3k green twill — decorative option - 650 g 12k twill — heavy, budget-friendly stiffness - 450 g 12k twill - 300 g 3k biaxial ±45° — for torsional strength

Carbon ribbons: - 80 g spread-tow ribbon, 15 mm — useful for reinforcement strips along rails or centerline.

Epoxy resin: - EL2 Epoxy Laminating Resin

docs.title: Prep and Vacuum
docs.text:
• Easylease chemical release agent or Mould Release Wax
  • Peel Ply
  • Breather Fabric
  • Vacuum Bagging Film — useful video: VB160 tutorial

docs.title: Support Base
docs.text:
I’ll need a flat sheet to laminate against:

  • Polycarbonate glazing sheet
  • Wickes Durable Clear Acrylic Sheet
  • Toolstation polycarbonate sheet

I still need to test which one works best. Acrylic scratches, polycarbonate might flex, but both should be fine for smaller training fins.

docs.title: Layering and Sizes
docs.text:
From the references I found:

  • Leaderfins → 7–8 layers, blade size ~24 cm × 54 cm
  • C4 → 7 layers, but much longer (around 90 cm)
  • DIY YouTube builds → around 6 layers

For a short training bifin, I’m probably aiming at 6–7 layers, depending on stiffness.

Reference image: Leaderfins carbon stereofins

docs.title: Finishing
docs.text:
Rails: - Waterway fin rails kit - Rail glues mentioned: Loctite 480 or 3M Marine 5200 - Good reading on rails: Spearfishing World thread

The rails help channel water and also protect the blade edge.

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• Easy Composites Laminating Starter Kit
  • Easy Composites vacuum bagging film tutorial
  • Leaderfins carbon stereofins photo

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
For a short carbon training bifin, I’ll probably go with: - ~6–7 layers of 200 g 3k fabric, maybe mixing in a heavier layer (450–650 g) for stiffness - EL2 epoxy resin - Laminating on an acrylic/polycarbonate sheet - Adding rails with Loctite 480 after trimming

This should give me a small, stiff blade that can take some abuse during training without overcomplicating the build.

docs.title: Research Notes: DIY Carbon Monofin BOM
docs.text:
After mapping out bifins, I want to gather materials and design notes for building a monofin blade. This will be a bit more complex than bifins because monofins need more lateral stability and usually use internal reinforcements.

The problems I need to solve are: 1. Which materials carry over from the bifin build 2. What extra elements a monofin blade needs (ribs, edge trims, reinforcements) 3. Typical dimensions of monofins 4. How many layers are used in commercial examples 5. How to finish the blade for durability

docs.title: Core Materials
docs.text:
Most of the BOM is the same as the bifins:

  • Carbon cloths (200–650 g, plain weave, twill, biaxial)
  • Carbon ribbons (spread-tow strips for reinforcement)
  • EL2 epoxy laminating resin
  • Release agent / mould wax
  • Peel ply + breather + vacuum bagging film

docs.title: Monofin-Specific Materials
docs.text:
• Rubber U-channel trim — protects blade edges from chipping
  • Neoprene strips / rubber — add lateral stiffness and stabilize the blade
  • High-density neoprene sheet — used in some designs for damping and structural support

These help with lateral stability, which is critical in a wide monofin blade.

docs.title: Sizes and Dimensions
docs.text:
Some references from commercial monofins:

  • Molchanovs PRO Monofin 4 (Regular): 72–74 cm length × 70 cm width
  • Molchanovs PRO Monofin 4 (Small): 70–72 cm length × 68 cm width
  • Cetma Taras Monofin: max width ~69 cm

So the range seems to be 70–74 cm wide, 68–74 cm long.

Reference article: Apneapassion on Cetma Taras dimensions

docs.title: Layering
docs.text:
From examples I’ve seen:

  • 10+ layers is common for full carbon monofins
  • Many use internal carbon ribs for stiffness distribution

Visual references: - Oceaner monofin layering - Cetma Taras internal structure - Bluewater Freediving ribs example

docs.title: Internal and Side Reinforcements
docs.text:
Most high-end monofins use reinforcement structures:

  • Internal ribs: strips of carbon inside the laminate for stiffness
  • Strong side ribs: thicker rails or carbon laminates that act like wings, resisting side flex
  • Examples:
  • Waterway 6-rib system
  • Molchanovs monofin
  • Goldfin side ribs
  • Junko Kitahama competition fin

docs.title: Finishing
docs.text:
• Edge protection: rubber U-channel trim
  • Rails (optional, depending on how stable the blade feels)
  • Sanded and rounded blade edges for safety and durability

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• DIY monofin forum thread
  • Cetma Taras monofin breakdown
  • Oceaner carbon monofin layering
  • Bluewater Freediving internal ribs example

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
Compared to bifins, a DIY monofin clearly needs: - More layers (10+) for stiffness - Internal ribs to control flex and power transfer - Side reinforcements to prevent wobbling - Rubber edge trim for protection

The challenge will be building internal ribs into the laminate. That’s probably the biggest difference compared to the simpler bifin build.

docs.title: Research Notes: Blade Stiffness and Profiles
docs.text:
I finally pulled together a quick reference for how tip load ("hardness") and bending profile play together on long freediving blades. The clearest explanation I have found so far comes from this breakdown: ▶️ Blade stiffness explained.

The short version: two variables define how a blade feels in the water.

  • Load (tip stiffness in kg) — how much weight it takes to bend the blade to 90°.
  • Bending profile — where the blade gives way once it reaches that load.

The Fin Flex Comparison Chart and its stiffness plot show fin stiffness spanning roughly 15–40 units of force across the models compared.

Ninety degrees is the useful limit. After that the blade just folds over, stalls, and stops storing energy. Most long fins (XT Diving, C4, Leaderfins, etc.) fall in the 80–90 cm length range, so that’s the baseline for comparing these values.

The nuance: fins that bend closer to the footpocket always feel softer—even if the tip load matches a “harder” blade. When the flex starts near your feet the blade unloads early, the water sheds faster, and the kick feels lighter. If the bend moves toward the tip, it holds shape longer and feels stiffer.

docs.title: Hardness vs. Profile Table
docs.text:
Kg Tip Load Type 1 Type 2 Type 3 Type 4 Type 5 0.7 X X X X SSS 0.8 X X SSS SSS SS 0.9 X SSS SS SS S 1.0 SSS SS S - SS S MS 1.1 SS S S MS M 1.2 S S - MS MS M M - MH 1.3 MS MS - M MS - M MH H 1.4 M M M H HH 1.5 M MH MH HH HHH 1.6 MH H H HHH X 1.7 H HH HH X X 1.8 H HH X X X

Legend: SSS = very soft, SS = soft, S = slightly soft, MS = medium soft, M = medium, MH = medium hard, H = hard, HH/HHH = very hard, X = not recommended.

docs.title: Technique Notes
docs.text:
Profiles 1, 2, and 3 reward short, hip-driven kicks with a small amplitude. Overkicking just pushes them beyond the 90° sweet spot and you lose efficiency. Profiles 4 and 5 hang onto stiffness longer, so they tolerate larger kicks before collapsing.

For training, I’m leaning toward the softer profiles paired with a 0.9–1.1 kg tip load. They feel forgiving, still snap back cleanly, and keep the effort focused on clean technique instead of raw leg power.

docs.title: Research Notes: Playing With Cantilever Beam Calculator for Fin Blades
docs.text: I wanted to see how a simple cantilever beam model matches what happens with freediving fins. The idea is that a fin blade is essentially a thin rectangular beam clamped at the footpocket and loaded at the tip by the force of the water.

docs.title: Young’s modulus
docs.text:
• Prepreg sheet (Easy Composites high-strength carbon fibre sheet): ~32.4 GPa
  • Wet layup + vacuum bagging: 20–40 GPa, depending on resin content and fibre fraction
    • More resin → lower \(E\)
    • Better fibre alignment and compaction → higher \(E\)

docs.title: Moment of inertia \(I\)
docs.text:
For a rectangular section:

\[ I = \frac{b h^{3}}{12} \]
  • Blade width: \(b = 180\,\text{mm}\)
  • Thickness (3 layers @ 0.31 mm each): \(h = 0.93\,\text{mm}\)
\[ I \approx 12.1\,\text{mm}^4 \]

⚠️ This assumes uniform thickness along the length. Real fins are tapered, so actual \(I(x)\) varies with position.

docs.title: Cantilever beam calculator inputs
docs.text:
Using the online cantilever calculator:

  • Structure
    • Length \(L = 250\,\text{mm}\)
    • Elastic modulus \(E = 32\,\text{GPa} = 32{,}000\,\text{N/mm}^2\)
    • Moment of inertia \(I = 12\,\text{mm}^4\)
  • Imposed loading
    • Point load at tip
    • \(P = 2\,\text{kg}\)

docs.title: Results
docs.text: • Tip slope: ~–91°

docs.title: Takeaway
docs.text:
With only 2 kg load at the tip, the test piece bends almost to a right angle. This matches freediving practice: once a fin bends to ~90°, extra load doesn’t increase thrust, because the blade is already “giving way” to the water.

This simple cantilever model helps build some intuition into how many layers are needed to achieve a desired stiffness.

docs.title: Research Notes: Blade Lengths for Freediving
docs.text:
I finally pulled together a quick comparison of what "long" and "short" blades actually mean for bifins. Across the usual depth fin brands there is a pretty clear split between competition-length blades and travel/pool blades.

The tables below track total blade length, the "free" blade that extends past the footpocket, and any extra notes on where the numbers come from. It's not exhaustive, but it gives a feel for the ranges.

docs.title: Long blades
docs.text: Model Total length (mm) Free blade (mm) Width (mm) Link Notes Cetma Taras Carbon ~800 (650 + 150 footpocket) 650 190 Link Used by Mateusz Malina & William Joy. XT Pro (Pteryx Long Wide) 870 ~720 190 Link — Molchanovs Sport Bifin 3 Carbon 760 600 190 Link Used by Alexey Molchanov.

docs.title: Short blades
docs.text: Model Total length (mm) Free blade (mm) Width (mm) Link Notes Prussian Blue Travel (PB50) 550 400 220 Link — Molchanovs Sport Short Carbon 570 420 200 Link —

docs.title: Quick takeaways
docs.text:
• Long fins run about 760–870 mm total with a 600–720 mm free blade. These are the depth workhorses.
  • Short fins are around 550–570 mm total with a 400–420 mm free blade. Easy to travel with and great for pool drills.

I'm leaning toward keeping both pairs in rotation: long blades for serious depth days, short blades for technique and pool work without hauling a massive fin bag around.

docs.title: Release: Predicting Flex Calculator
docs.text: The new Predicting Flex page is now live with the tapered cantilever beam calculator embedded on it.

docs.title: Materials Directory
docs.text:
A central catalogue of the consumables and components referenced across ApneaScrap Lab. Each material page explains what to look for, regional supplier options, and which builds use it.

Use this directory to find locally sourced alternatives without the technique pages being tied to one country or store. When documenting a new technique, link to the relevant material pages instead of listing suppliers directly.

docs.title: How to contribute
docs.text:
1. Create or update the material page with a short description, recommended specifications, and any sourcing notes.
  2. Group supplier links under regional headings (e.g. United Kingdom, European Union, North America) so readers can quickly spot local options.
  3. Add the technique or project that depends on the material to the "Related Techniques" section of the material page.
  4. Update the bill of materials in the technique so it links back to the material page.

Need a new material? Duplicate the template below.

---
title: Example Material
---
# Example Material

## Overview
Describe the purpose of the material and what to look for.

## Recommended Specs
- Bullet points covering weights, dimensions, compatible systems, etc.

## Regional Suppliers
### United Kingdom
- [Supplier name](url) — short note on why it is relevant

### European Union
- ...

### North America
- ...

## Related Techniques
- [Technique name](../techniques/...)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Clear acrylic sheet is used to create smooth laminating surfaces and angled supports for blades. It stays rigid under mild vacuum and is easy to cut with woodworking tools.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Cast acrylic (PMMA) for better clarity and scratch resistance
  • Thickness 3–5 mm for laminating bases; thicker sheets resist bending
  • Supplied with protective film to avoid surface scratches during transport

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Perspex Distribution — Cut-to-size service with colour and thickness options
  • Sheet Plastics — Quick delivery of standard A3/A4 sizes

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Kunststoffplattenonline — Custom sizes and edge finishing across the EU
  • Modulor — Stocks Perspex and alternative cast acrylic sheets

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Tap Plastics — In-store cutting and online ordering for acrylic
  • Acme Plastics — Offers bulk sheets and cut-to-size services

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Creating Laminating Base – V1 Wood Support
  • Creating Laminating Base – V2 Acrylic Wedges

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Breather cloth maintains airflow across the laminate when under vacuum and helps absorb excess resin that bleeds through the stack. It is often polyester batting or felt.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Polyester or nylon breather compatible with epoxy systems
  • Thickness 3–6 mm to prevent bridging
  • Supplied in rolls so it can be wrapped around parts

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites Medium Breather — Soft polyester felt cut-friendly for small parts
  • VacuPress — Carries heavier breather for higher vacuum levels

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• R&G Breather Fabric 200 g/m² — Works with both resin infusion and vacuum bagging
  • HP-Textiles HP-B100 — Lightweight breather sold by the metre

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Fibre Glast Polyester Breather — Ideal for small vacuum bags
  • Airtech Airweave® N10 — Industry staple with consistent loft

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V1 Enclosed Bagging
  • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V2 Edge-Sealed Bagging

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Butyl sealant tape creates airtight seams between vacuum bag film and tooling surfaces. It must remain tacky throughout the cure cycle so leaks can be patched quickly.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• 3–4 mm diameter round or rectangular profile
  • Compatible with nylon bag film and room-temperature cures
  • Non-silicone to avoid contaminating subsequent bonding

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites Flash-Break Butyl Tape — Easy to reposition during setup
  • Aerovac ST-8 — Higher temperature rating for warm cures

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• R&G Butyl Sealant Tape — Available in 7.5 m rolls, tolerant up to 130 °C
  • HP-Textiles HP-BT10 — Long rolls for repeated bagging runs

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Fibre Glast Sealant Tape — Reliable seal at room temperature
  • Airtech Flash Tape ST-95 — Versatile tape for composites bagging

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text: • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V2 Edge-Sealed Bagging

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Carbon cloth forms the structural backbone of the blades. A 200–240 g/m² 3K twill or plain weave is flexible enough for bifins while still providing strength. Choose fabric widths that cover the full blade plus trimming allowance.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• 3K 2/2 twill or plain weave carbon cloth
  • 200–240 g/m² are versatile weights for fin laminates
  • Supplied on the roll to minimise creases; store flat and dry

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites — Wide range of 3K twill fabrics in small roll lengths
  • East Coast Fibreglass Supplies — Offers 1 m cuts and heavier weights for stiffer layups

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• R&G Faserverbundwerkstoffe — Ships 200 g/m² 3K cloth throughout the EU
  • HP-Textiles — Multiple weave styles with sample cuts for prototyping

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Fibre Glast — Twill and plain weave rolls with spec sheets
  • Soller Composites — Offers narrower widths ideal for fin blades

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Laminating Carbon – V1 Wet Layup
  • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V1 Enclosed Bagging
  • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V2 Edge-Sealed Bagging

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Clear acrylic or polyurethane spray coats protect exposed carbon surfaces and add gloss. Look for coatings compatible with epoxy substrates and capable of curing at room temperature.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Transparent acrylic or polyurethane clear coat
  • Fast drying (<1 hour between coats) to limit dust pick-up
  • UV inhibitors to slow yellowing when exposed to sunlight

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Hycote Double Acrylic Lacquer — Readily available automotive clear coat
  • Halfords Clear Lacquer — Easy to find nationwide

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Motip Acrylic Clear Varnish — Widely stocked automotive clear coat
  • SprayMax 2K Clear Coat — Two-component option for higher chemical resistance

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Rust-Oleum Automotive Enamel — Accessible clear coat for carbon finishing
  • Krylon Fusion Clear — Good adhesion to composite surfaces

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text: • Finishing Carbon – V1 Epoxy and Clear Coat

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Thin double-sided tape secures acrylic skins and templates during setup without adding bulk. Removable tapes let you reposition parts while still holding them in place during vacuum bagging.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Thickness below 0.2 mm to avoid imprinting through laminates
  • Acrylic adhesive for strong hold on plastics and wood
  • Supplied on rolls wider than 10 mm for easy application

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• 3M 9088 — High-tack acrylic adhesive widely available from industrial distributors
  • Tesa 4965 — Performs well on acrylic at room temperature

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Weicon Double-Sided Tape — Stocked by many EU tooling suppliers
  • RS PRO Acrylic Tape — Ships EU-wide with multiple widths

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• 3M VHB 4910 (thin variants) — Transparent tape that bonds acrylic securely
  • Uline Industrial Tape — Budget-friendly rolls for workshop use

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text: • Creating Laminating Base – V1 Wood Support

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A balanced resin and hardener system is critical for strong, void-free laminates. Look for low-viscosity epoxies formulated for hand layup or vacuum bagging, with medium cure speeds that allow adequate working time.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Mix ratio specified by weight (commonly 100:30 or 100:35)
  • Pot life of 20–40 minutes at 20 °C for relaxed layups
  • Low viscosity (<600 mPa·s) to wet 3K carbon cloth thoroughly
  • Room-temperature cure with option for post-cure if higher Tg is needed

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites EL2 + AT30 — Popular 100:30 system with full data sheets
  • Tamek — Supplies West System laminating epoxies with slow and fast hardeners

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Sicomin SR1710 + SD7820 — Thin resin with multiple hardener speeds, certified for marine use
  • HP-Textiles HP-E45KL — Affordable kits sized for small projects

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Fibre Glast System 2000 — Laminating epoxy with hardener options
  • Composite Envisions Pro-Glas 1800 — Offers quart kits suitable for prototyping

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Laminating Carbon – V1 Wet Layup
  • Finishing Carbon – V1 Epoxy and Clear Coat

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Manual pumps are useful for small laminating setups where electric vacuum pumps are overkill. Hand-operated piston or lever pumps let you evacuate compact vacuum bags while keeping the kit portable.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Compatible hose barb or valve adapter for storage bags or bagging film
  • Capable of reaching at least -0.6 bar on small volumes
  • Durable seals that tolerate repeated cycles without oiling

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Vacuum Pressing Systems Thin Air Press Pump — Compact hand pump suited to composites experimentation
  • Sealey VS016 — Automotive vacuum pump with gauge and hose adaptors

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Schmalz Manual Vacuum Pump — Industrial-grade option with replaceable seals
  • DICTUM Vacuum Press Kit Pump — Woodworking pump that doubles for composites bagging

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Roarockit Thin Air Press Pump — Widely used for skateboard pressing and small composites work
  • Mityvac MV8500 — Automotive hand pump capable of sustained vacuum

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V1 Enclosed Bagging
  • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V2 Edge-Sealed Bagging

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Peel ply is a porous nylon fabric laid on top of the laminate before cure. Once removed, it leaves a textured surface ready for secondary bonding and helps wick away excess resin during vacuum processing.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Nylon or polyester peel ply rated for epoxy use
  • Plain weave, 85–105 g/m²
  • Supplied without silicone release coatings to allow bonding after removal

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites Release Peel Ply — Stocked in 1 m cuts and full rolls
  • East Coast Fibreglass Supplies — Offers perforated options when more bleed is needed

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• R&G Nylon Peel Ply 85 g/m² — Consistent weave for clear imprint
  • HP-Textiles HP-P100 — Available in 50 cm width for smaller projects

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Fibre Glast Nylon Peel Ply — Heat-set to reduce fraying
  • Airtech Release Ease 234TFP — Industry standard peel ply with detailed datasheets

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Laminating Carbon – V1 Wet Layup
  • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V2 Edge-Sealed Bagging

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Two-part structural adhesives bond rubber or plastic rails to composite blades. Look for methacrylate or polyurethane systems designed for mixed-material bonding and with workable cure times.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Two-part cartridge or syringe for accurate mixing
  • Fixture time between 5–15 minutes to allow alignment
  • Tensile shear strength above 15 MPa on composites

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites Polyurethane Adhesive — Flexible bond suitable for rails
  • JB Weld PlasticWeld/PlasticBonder — Widely stocked in DIY stores

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• R&G Methacrylate Adhesive — High strength for composite-to-plastic joints
  • Sicomin PB 250 — Bonds rubber trims to composite blades

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Lord 406/19 — Proven methacrylate adhesive for composite repair
  • 3M Scotch-Weld DP8005 — Designed for low surface energy plastics with primer-free bonding

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text: • Gluing Fin Rails – V1 Two Part Plastic-to-Carbon Adhesive

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) release agents form a sacrificial film that stops epoxy from bonding to tooling surfaces. They are ideal for sealing laminating bases and moulds that do not have a permanent release coating.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Water-based PVA formulated for epoxy and polyester systems
  • Sprayable or brushable viscosity depending on your tooling finish
  • Dries to a thin, even film in under 30 minutes at room temperature

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites TR104 — Brush or spray, compatible with epoxy layups
  • EC Fibreglass — Supplies PVA and complementary wax systems

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• R&G PVA Release — Available in 0.5 L bottles, works with epoxy and polyester resins
  • HP-Textiles HP-PVA — Sold with atomisers for even coats

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Fibre Glast PVA Release Film #13 — PVA compatible with epoxy
  • Airtech Blue PVA — Industrial grade release agent in multiple bottle sizes

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Laminating Carbon – V1 Wet Layup
  • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V1 Enclosed Bagging

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Rubber rails protect blade edges and guide water flow along fins. Choose rails designed for composite freediving blades so they fit securely while allowing the blade to flex.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Shore A hardness 60–70 for a balance of grip and flexibility
  • Inner profile sized for 2–3 mm blade thickness
  • Available in lengths long enough for full blade perimeter (typically 1.6 m per fin)

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• DiveSports UK — Replacement rails compatible with Pathos and similar foot pockets
  • Apnea Products — Stocks soft and stiff rail profiles

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Leaderfins Spare Rails — Offers medium and hard rails with international shipping
  • Finisimo — Italian supplier for custom-length rails

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Specialfins USA — Ships universal rails for DIY blade builders
  • Mako Spearguns — Carries spare bi-fin rails and hardware

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Gluing Fin Rails – V1 Two Part Plastic-to-Carbon Adhesive
  • Choosing Bi-fin Foot Pockets – V1 Short Rails

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Dedicated vacuum bag film allows custom-sized enclosures around larger laminates. Look for nylon or multilayer films that can handle the temperatures and vacuum levels used in composites work.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Nylon or co-polymer film rated for -0.9 bar vacuum
  • Thickness 60–80 microns for hand layup
  • Compatible with chosen sealing tape temperature range

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Easy Composites VACfilm 300 — Handles room and elevated cure cycles
  • VacuPress VF200 — Wide roll widths for large fins or multiple parts

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• R&G Vacu 2 Nylon Film — 75 µm nylon film supplied in folded rolls
  • HP-Textiles HP-BF56 — Affordable film available by the metre

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Fibre Glast Stretchlon 200 — Elastic film that reduces bridging
  • Airtech Wrightlon 7400 — Industry standard with temperature headroom up to 180 °C

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text: • Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V2 Edge-Sealed Bagging

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A vacuum gauge helps you monitor seal quality and repeatability. For hand layups, analogue gauges with hose barbs are easy to install inline with manual pumps or bag valves.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Range 0 to -1 bar (0 to 30 inHg) with clear markings around -0.2 to -0.8 bar
  • 1/4" BSP/NPT or hose barb connection compatible with bag fittings
  • Oil-filled gauges resist vibration and make leaks easier to spot

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• RS PRO Vacuum Gauges — Multiple dial sizes with BSP threads
  • Vacuum Pressing Systems Gauge Kit — Includes hose barb adapter for Thin Air Press setups

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Güde Vacuum Gauge — Affordable gauges for workshop use
  • HPC KAESER Accessories — Industrial gauges with protective casings

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• McMaster-Carr Vacuum Gauges — Wide selection of oil-filled gauges
  • Roarockit Inline Gauge — Designed for skateboard pressing vacuum systems

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V2 Edge-Sealed Bagging
  • Measuring Vacuum – V1 Syringe Gauge

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Household vacuum compression bags can double as low-cost vacuum chambers for small laminates. Choose heavy-duty bags with a valve that accepts generic pumps and ensure seams can withstand repeated cycles.

docs.title: Recommended Specs
docs.text:
• Multi-layer PA/PE film at least 90 microns thick
  • Screw-valve compatible with hand pumps or vacuum hoses
  • Large enough to fit the laminating base with breather cloth clearance

docs.title: United Kingdom
docs.text:
• Lakeland Vacuum Storage Bags — Durable seams and replacement valve gaskets
  • SpaceSaver Premium Bags — Includes manual pump for travel use

docs.title: European Union
docs.text:
• Compactor Lifebox Bags — Reinforced valves and wide size selection
  • Ikea Jämlik — Budget option widely stocked across the EU

docs.title: North America
docs.text:
• Ziploc Space Bag — Available in most hardware stores with multiple sizes
  • VacuFlat Bags — Thick film better suited to repeated composites work

docs.title: Related Techniques
docs.text:
• Vacuum Bagging Carbon – V1 Enclosed Bagging
  • Laminating Carbon – V1 Wet Layup

docs.title: Choosing Bi-fin Foot Pockets Versions
docs.text:
Choosing bifin footpockets.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Short Rails Active GBP 40-90 (UK) N/Ah N/Ah

docs.title: Choosing Bi-fin Foot Pockets - V1 - Short Rails
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Choose the right freediving foot pockets for DIY carbon blades, focusing on performance-critical features.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Foot pocket rails: short to allow the carbon blade to flex freely
  • Blade angle: 20°–33° for better body position and surface gliding
  • Attachment system: two-point (blade pocket + screws) for secure hold

docs.title: Reference Images
docs.text: Example Foot pocket

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Check rail length

    • Choose pockets with short or low-profile rails so the blade can bend and return energy efficiently (see rubber fin rails for sourcing options).
    • Avoid long or stiff rails that dampen flex, especially on short training blades.

  2. Check blade angle

    • Select pockets with 20°–33° blade angle.
    • Larger angles favor surface swimming and gliding.
    • Smaller angles or flat pockets may feel more responsive but are less efficient for pool or surface work.

  3. Check attachment system

    • Ensure the pockets use a two-point attachment:
      • Blade slides into the pocket slot
      • Screws lock it in place
    • This system is standard for modern freediving pockets and ensures a secure, repeatable fit.
Picasso Supreme

docs.title: Creating Laminating Base Versions
docs.text:
Surfaces and jigs that hold the blade during lamination.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V2 - Plastic Wedges Research GBP 10 (UK) 1h 0h V1 - Wood Support Active GBP 20 (UK) 3h 0h

docs.title: Creating Laminating Base - V1 - Wood Support
docs.text:
Active

25° wooden base with acrylic sheets for laminating carbon fin blades.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Create a rigid angled surface to support fin blades during lamination.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
Dimensions

  • Long Side (Flat):
    • Minimum width: 25cm (to accommodate 20cm blade width and additional room).
    • Minimum length: 30cm (to fit a 25cm blade length and additional room).
  • Angled Side (23°–25° Incline):
    • Angle: 23 degrees (or 25° based on matching geometry).
    • Minimum width: 25cm (to match blade width).
    • Minimum length: 20cm (to fit 15cm blade length and extra space).

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
1. Acrylic sheet
    • 1× A3 size: 42 cm × 30 cm.
    • 1× A4 size: 30 cm × 21 cm.
  2. Wooden components
    • DIY timber for constructing the base, 1 cm thick.
  3. Brackets and screws
    • 2× metal brackets with screws (1.6 cm).
  4. Adhesive
    • Thin double-sided tape to hold the acrylic sheets onto the wooden structure.

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Cutting Tools: Wood saw.
  • Assembly Tools: Screwdriver and screws for securing brackets.
  • Measurement and Finishing: Measuring tools (square, protractor, tape measure). Sandpaper for smoothing wood edges.

docs.title: Reference Images
docs.text: Full Support Structure Brackets and Side Supports

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Base Construction

    • Use 1cm thick timber to create a solid base.
    • Cut wooden side supports to a 23°–25° angle to replicate blade geometry.
    • Secure side supports to the flat base using metal brackets for rigidity.

  2. Laminating Platform

    • Tape clear Acrylic Perspex sheets (A3 and A4 sizes) onto the wooden base using thin double-sided adhesive tape.
    • Ensure the surface is smooth and taut to properly press against the blade.

docs.title: Data to Record / Results
docs.text:
• Notes on surface flatness after cure
  • Any deformation or movement during lamination

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Does not scale well: In order to create bigger fins, the wooden structure needs to be re-worked.
  • Vacuum Bag Fit: Ensure the base with acrylic layers fits entirely into the vacuum bag.
  • Air Trapping Issue: The gap between the angled section and wooden supports bends the acrylic during vacuum bagging

docs.title: Creating Laminating Base - V2 - Plastic Wedges
docs.text:
Research

This document describes how to build a modular acrylic base with wedge supports for laminating carbon fins. The example shown is for a 70 × 70 cm monofin, but the same technique can be adapted for bifins or other blade sizes.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Provide a modular surface with adjustable wedges to support blades during lamination.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Target working area (monofin example): ~80 × 90 cm
  • Purpose: Provides enough surface for a 70 × 70 cm monofin blade plus sealing margin
  • Support requirement: Must be placed on a flat, rigid surface such as a table or workbench
  • Protection: Place a plastic sheet under the base to protect the table surface

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• 6 × acrylic sheets (2 mm thick)
  • 4 sheets for the flat blade section (2 wide × 2 tall)
  • 2 sheets for the angled footpocket section
  • Electrical tape for sealing the joints
  • Plastic stackable wedges to create the angled section under the footpockets
  • Protective plastic sheet (to cover the table surface beneath the acrylic)

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Isopropyl alcohol and cloth (for cleaning sheet edges)
  • Scissors or knife (for trimming electrical tape)
  • Measuring tape or ruler (for alignment)
  • Squeegee, roller, or thumb pressure (for pressing tape flush)

docs.title: Time Required
docs.text:
• Base assembly: ~30 minutes
  • Wedge placement & alignment: ~10 minutes

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Prepare the surface

    • Place a plastic sheet on a flat, rigid table or bench.
    • Ensure there is no dust or debris under the plastic.

  2. Arrange acrylic sheets

    • Flat blade section: 4 A3 sheets in a 2 × 2 layout (~59 × 84 cm).
    • Footpocket section: 2 A3 sheets side by side (~29.7 × 84 cm).

  3. Join sheets

    • Clean edges with isopropyl alcohol.
    • Bridge each joint with electrical tape, overlapping slightly (1–2 mm).
    • Press tape firmly to remove trapped air and keep surface flush.

  4. Add wedge supports

    • Place plastic stackable wedges under the footpocket section.
    • Adjust wedge height to set the required angle (typically 20–30° for a monofin).
    • Ensure wedges are stable and evenly distributed.

docs.title: Data to Record / Results
docs.text:
• Wedge heights and resulting angles
  • Notes on surface gaps or leaks during lamination

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• This version does not require a heavy wooden support structure, making it much easier and faster to put together.
  • Modular design — acrylic sheets and wedges can be stored flat and reused for different versions.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• The base cannot be placed as a whole into a vacuum bag.
  • The only viable vacuum method is sealing the edges of the bag around the acrylic surface, which is less flexible than a solid one-piece base.

docs.title: Cutting Cured Carbon Versions
docs.text:
Different ways of cutting cured carbon parts.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Junior Hacksaw Active GBP 10 (UK) 1h 0h

docs.title: Cutting Cured Carbon - V1 - Junior Hacksaw
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To cut cured carbon laminate into the desired shape using a simple junior hacksaw method, ensuring a clean fit into the final assembly.

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• Printed or drawn cutting template
  • Electrical tape (to attach the template to the laminate)

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Junior hacksaw with a fine-tooth metal blade
  • Metal file
  • Safety goggles, dust mask, and protective gloves

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Safety: Wear gloves, eye protection, and a dust mask. Perform all steps in a well-ventilated area.
  2. Attach the cutting template to the cured laminate using electrical tape.
  3. Hold the laminate securely on a stable surface.
  4. Use a junior hacksaw with a fine-tooth metal blade to slowly cut along the template line. Apply steady pressure and avoid forcing the saw.
  5. Once the piece is cut, smooth the edges with a metal file.
  6. Test the fit by inserting the blade into the foot pocket.
  7. If it does not fit properly, continue filing the edges gradually until the correct fit is achieved.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Sawing generates dust and small splinters — PPE is required
  • Cutting is slow and requires quite some effort, depending on how thick the laminate is

docs.title: Inspiration
docs.text: • How to make carbon fibre fins at home (minute 8:21)

docs.title: Cutting Template Versions
docs.text:
Cutting templates are essential for creating precise and repeatable fin shapes. Here you'll find different techniques for making durable templates to assist in cutting fins.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Paper Laminate Active GBP 20 (UK) 3h 0h

docs.title: Cutting Template - V1 - Paper Laminate
docs.text:
Active

This technique shows how to create a cutting template for fins using laminated paper.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Produce a durable template that matches the foot pocket outline.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text: • Sized to the chosen foot pocket and blade design

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• Paper sheets (standard or heavy-duty for added stiffness)
  • Lamination film or clear adhesive sheets

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Scissors or precision cutting tool
  • Pen or pencil for tracing

docs.title: Reference Images
docs.text: Paper Template Traced Cutting Template Back Cutting Template Front

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Print the Template
    • Print the provided A4 graph paper: Download the Graph Paper
  2. Laminate the Paper
    • Apply lamination film or clear adhesive sheets to both sides for durability.
    • Smooth the film to avoid air bubbles and ensure it adheres properly.
  3. Trace an approximate contour
    • Look at the foot pocket and trace an approximate contour (precision comes later).
  4. Cut the Template
    • Carefully cut along the traced outline using scissors.
    • Make sure the edges are smooth and well-defined.
  5. Verify the Template
    • Try to fit the template into a foot pocket.
    • Adjust any rough edges to ensure accuracy.

docs.title: Limitation
docs.text: • Laminated paper is not stiff enough and might warp when pushed into the foot pocket

docs.title: Finishing Carbon Versions
docs.text:
Different ways of surface-finishing the cured carbon laminated.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Epoxy and Clear Coat Active GBP 10 (UK) 1h 0h

docs.title: Finishing Carbon - V1 - Epoxy and Clear Coat
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To apply a protective and aesthetic finish to cured carbon blades by sealing, smoothing, and clear-coating the surface. This improves durability, protects against moisture, enhances gloss, and provides the option for custom decals.

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
From DIY stores: - Clear coat spray (acrylic or polyurethane lacquer)

Optional: - Premium printable vinyl sticker paper (for decals/logos)

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Mixing cups (for resin + hardener)
  • Small brush (for epoxy layer)
  • Sandpaper (400 / 600 grit; 1000 grit optional for higher gloss)
  • Gloves
  • Eye protection
  • Well-ventilated workspace

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Safety

    • Wear gloves and eye protection.
    • Work in a well-ventilated area.

  2. Resin Finishing Layer

    • Mix resin and hardener as usual.
    • Apply a thin finishing coat with a brush over the cured carbon surface.
    • Smooth out imperfections.
    • Allow resin to fully cure.
    • Clean the brush immediately after use.

  3. Optional Sanding

    • If a smoother or glossier surface is desired, sand the cured resin lightly.
    • Start with 400 grit, then move to 600 grit.
    • Finish with 1000 grit if you want a mirror-like polish.
    • Skip this step if surface smoothness is not critical.

  4. Optional Decal Application

    • Print the logo onto the back of vinyl sticker paper. Download the printable logo

    • Cut out the design.

    • Apply the decal carefully onto the carbon surface.

  5. Clear Coat

    • Spray the entire surface with acrylic clear coat.
    • Apply 3 light, even layers.
    • Allow proper drying time between layers.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Requires time and patience for curing and sanding.
  • Gloss finish depends on sanding quality and spray application.

docs.title: Inspiration
docs.text: • How to make carbon fibre fins at home (minute 8:40)

docs.title: Gluing Fin Rails Versions
docs.text:
Methods for attaching rubber rails to fin edges.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Two Part Plastic-to-Carbon Adhesive Active GBP 15 (UK) 1h 12h

docs.title: Gluing Fin Rails - V1 - Two Part Plastic-to-Carbon Adhesive
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To attach rubber fin rails securely to carbon fiber blades using a strong composite adhesive. The rails protect the blade edges, improve water flow, and extend the blade’s lifespan.

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• Rubber fin rails
  • Plastic-to-carbon adhesive
  • Fold-back paper clips (for clamping)

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Gloves
  • Sandpaper (around 400 grit)
  • Window cleaner (for cleaning surfaces)

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Safety

    • Wear gloves to avoid skin contact with adhesive.
    • Work in a ventilated space.

  2. Surface Preparation

    • Sand the edge of the carbon blade lightly with 400-grit sandpaper.
    • Sand the inside surface of the rubber fin rail to improve adhesion.
    • Clean both the blade edge and the inside of the rail with window cleaner.

  3. Apply Adhesive

    • Mix the two-part adhesive according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
    • Apply the adhesive generously inside the fin rail.
    • Press the rail firmly onto the blade edge, ensuring full contact along the surface.
    • Check carefully for gaps — even small gaps can expand over time and risk detachment.

  4. Remove Excess Adhesive

    • Wipe off any excess adhesive that squeezes out during pressing.

  5. Clamp the Rails

    • Secure the rails in place using fold-back paper clips spaced evenly along the edge.

  6. Curing

    • Allow the adhesive to cure fully according to the manufacturer’s specifications (usually around 12 hours).

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Poor surface preparation (e.g., not sanding both blade edge and rail interior) may result in weak bonding.
  • Adhesive application must be uniform; gaps reduce durability and may lead to rail detachment over time.

docs.title: Inspiration
docs.text: • How to make carbon fibre fins at home (minute 10:00)

docs.title: Laminating Carbon Versions
docs.text:
Recipes for layering carbon fabric into fin blades.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Wet Layup Active GBP 20 (UK) 3h 12h

docs.title: Laminating Carbon - V1 - Wet Layup
docs.text:
Active

Baseline recipe with 0/90 twill and simple taper.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Produce a basic carbon blade using a manual wet layup.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Uses 0/90 3K twill carbon cloth
  • Geometry and taper follow the chosen cutting template

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• Carbon fiber fabric — 0.3 m² of 3K 2/2 twill cloth cut to the blade outline.
  • Laminating epoxy system — Mix 154 g resin with 46 g hardener (100:30 by weight).
  • PVA release agent — Approximately 35 ml to seal the laminating base.
  • Peel ply — Two layers covering the full laminate area.
  • Breather cloth — Optional wrap to improve vacuum bleed.
  • Vacuum storage bags with hand pump — Optional low-cost vacuum enclosure.
  • Disposable consumables: nitrile gloves, mixing pots, mixing sticks, laminating brushes, plastic finned roller, and acetone for cleanup.
  • Digital scale accurate to 1 g for measuring resin and hardener.

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Nitrile gloves
  • Mixing pots and sticks
  • Laminating brushes
  • Plastic finned roller (75 mm)
  • Scissors for cutting fabric
  • Digital scale
  • Optional: vacuum storage bags and hand pump

docs.title: Reference Images
docs.text: Wet Carbon Laminate Cured Carbon Laminate

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
0. Safety first

  • Wear nitrile gloves and work in a well-ventilated area to avoid exposure to harmful fumes.

1. Prepare the work surface

  1. Pour a small amount of the PVA mold release agent into a cup.
  2. Using a brush, apply the release agent thinly and evenly over the working surface or mold.
  3. Tip: see this video at 2:00 for guidance.

2. Cut the carbon fiber cloth

  • Measure and cut the carbon fiber cloth to the desired dimensions.
  • Ensure smooth cuts to maintain structural strength along the fiber weave.

3. Prepare the epoxy resin

  1. Pour epoxy resin into a mixing pot.
  2. Use a ratio of 100:30 by weight (resin:hardener).
  3. Example: for 100 g of resin, add 30 g of hardener.
  4. Use the digital scale for precise measurement.
  5. Mix the resin and hardener thoroughly, but gently, to avoid introducing air bubbles.

4. Lay the resin and carbon cloth

  1. Spread an even layer of resin directly onto the prepared mold or surface.
  2. Lay the carbon fiber cloth over the resin layer.
  3. Apply another layer of resin over the cloth using the brush and smooth it out with the roller.
  4. Tip: use the roller to eliminate trapped air and ensure the cloth adheres evenly.

5. Apply peel ply

  1. Once the laminate layers are complete, apply two layers of peel ply over the top surface.
  2. Peel ply absorbs excess resin and helps achieve a uniform finish.
  3. Optional: include a breather layer to improve vacuum results (future upgrade).
  4. Optional: if using vacuum storage bags, place the prepared laminate inside, seal, and apply vacuum pressure using the pump.

6. Clean-up

  1. Clean all reusable tools (e.g., brushes) with acetone immediately after use.
  2. Discard used gloves, cups, and mixing sticks responsibly.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Manual layup can trap more resin compared to vacuum processes.
  • Work time is limited once resin is mixed; prepare all materials in advance.

docs.title: Measuring Flex Versions
docs.text:
Simple setups for measuring how blades bend under load.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V2 - Kitchen Scale Test Active GBP 0 (UK) 0.25h 0h V1 - Weight Belt Test Superseded GBP 10 (UK) 0.25h 0h

docs.title: Measuring Flex - V1 - Weight Belt Test
docs.text: Superseded

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Measure the load required to make the tip vertical (90°) and observe where the blade bends (root, mid, tip).

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Clamp depth ≈80 mm on the blade root
  • Marks at 0.3 L (root), 0.6 L (mid), and 0.9 L (tip)
  • Weights applied in a 2:1 ratio (tip:mid)

docs.title: Materials
docs.text:
• Weight belt
  • Dive weights
  • Ruler or printed grid
  • Tape for securing the reference grid

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Clamp with rubber pads
  • Camera or smartphone
  • Angle finder or protractor

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
• Step 1 — Load until tip is vertical Add weights to tip and mid (2:1 ratio) and stop when the last 20 mm of the tip points straight (≈90°). Record the total weight.

Formula: F90 = m × 9.81 (N)

  • Step 2 — Measure bend at 3 zones Take a side photo at the load and estimate local slope (angle) at each zone:
  • θ_root at 0.3 L
  • θ_mid at 0.6 L
  • θ_tip at 0.9 L

docs.title: Data to Record
docs.text:
• Clamp depth (mm)
  • Blade span L (mm)
  • Load method: belt with weights on top (tip + mid, 2:1 ratio)
  • F90 (N)
  • θ_root, θ_mid, θ_tip (degrees at F90)

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text: • Dive weights limit fine-tuning of the scale

docs.title: Measuring Flex - V2 - Kitchen Scale Test
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Measure the load required to make the tip vertical (90°) and observe where the blade bends (root, mid, tip).

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: • Kitchen Scale

docs.title: Reference Images
docs.text: Kitchen Scale Test

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text: Firmly hold the blade just beyond the foot pocket angle, as this is the point where bending occurs. Gradually press until the blade tip lies flat against the kitchen scale, and note the weight reading. Repeat the process by bending the blade in the opposite direction.

docs.title: Data to Record
docs.text: • Load required to bend the fin to 90 degrees (Kg)

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Determining when the tip reaches a 90-degree angle is fairly approximate.
  • Holding the root of the blade vertically is also subjective.

docs.title: Measuring Vacuum Versions
docs.text:
Low-cost gauges to monitor vacuum pressure.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Syringe Gauge Research GBP 10 (UK) 1h 0h

docs.title: Measuring Vacuum - V1 - Syringe Gauge
docs.text:
Research

A simple gauge to monitor mild vacuum (~81 kPa absolute, −20 kPa gauge) directly inside a vacuum bag. It uses Boyle’s law: trapped air expands as pressure drops, moving a rubber plunger seal you can read through the bag.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Monitor vacuum level inside a bag using plunger movement.

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• 1 × syringe (10 mL or 20 mL, ideally thin barrel for more travel)
  • Luer-lock or push-on tip cap (to seal airtight)
  • Candle wax (for plunger lubrication)
  • Breather cloth (to wrap the gauge and protect from resin)
  • Permanent marker (to mark calibration lines)

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Knife or scissors (for trimming)
  • Permanent marker
  • Breather fabric

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Modify plunger

    • Remove plunger from syringe.
    • Cut off the plastic rod, leaving only the rubber seal.

  2. Prepare barrel

    • Clean inside of syringe.
    • Lightly rub candle wax on the rubber seal for low friction.

  3. Seal the syringe

    • Insert rubber seal back into barrel at the start volume:
      • 5 mL mark for a 10 mL syringe
      • 10 mL mark for a 20 mL syringe
    • Cap the tip airtight with a Luer-lock or push-on tip cap.

  4. Mark the scale

    • Draw an ambient mark at the initial plunger position.
    • Mark your target 80% atmospheric (~81 kPa abs):
      • 10 mL syringe → +1.25 mL (plunger moves ~7.6 mm on standard barrel, ~20 mm on thin insulin barrel)
      • 20 mL syringe → +2.5 mL (plunger moves ~8.9 mm)

  5. Wrap and place

    • Wrap syringe loosely in breather fabric so resin cannot touch it.
    • Place it on top of breather stack, markings facing upward for reading through film.

docs.title: Data to Record / Results
docs.text: Record plunger position at ambient and at target pressure.

docs.title: Calibration Reference
docs.text:
Target positions relative to start volume:

Absolute Pressure % of Atmosphere 10 mL Syringe (start 5 mL) 20 mL Syringe (start 10 mL) 101 kPa 100% (ambient) 5.0 mL 10.0 mL 95 kPa 94% 5.33 mL (Δ0.33) 10.67 mL (Δ0.67) 90 kPa 89% 5.63 mL (Δ0.63) 11.26 mL (Δ1.26) 85 kPa 84% 5.96 mL (Δ0.96) 11.92 mL (Δ1.92) 81 kPa 80% target 6.25 mL (Δ1.25) 12.5 mL (Δ2.5) 75 kPa 74% 6.75 mL (Δ1.75) 13.5 mL (Δ3.5)

Δ = plunger movement from ambient

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text: • The friction between the plunger and the barrel might affect precision

docs.title: Predicting Flex Versions
docs.text:
Use simplified beam theory to estimate how new blade geometries will bend under load.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Tapered Cantilever Beam Research GBP 0 (UK) 1h 0h

docs.title: Predicting Flex - V1 - Tapered Cantilever Beam
docs.text: Research

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
Estimate deflection and curvature profiles for a planned blade using simple inputs such as length, taper, and modulus, allowing iterative layup adjustments without material usage.

The process involves dividing the blade into many small slices, calculating the bending contribution of each slice based on layer thickness, and summing these contributions to determine the overall deflection. The applied load is adjusted until the tip reaches the desired angle, after which SVG visualizations and inertia values are generated.

The calculations follow Euler–Bernoulli beam theory principles. You can explore cantilever beam calculations here.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Simplifies the fin as a tapered Euler–Bernoulli beam, which may not capture all real-world complexities.
  • Approximates the values for E (modulus) and I (moment of inertia), making precise computation challenging.

docs.title: Vacuum Bagging Carbon Versions
docs.text:
Techniques for vacuum bagging carbon layups.

Version Status Estimated Cost Implementation Time (h) Waiting Time (h) V1 - Edge-Sealed Bagging Research GBP 35 (UK) 5h 12h V1 - Enclosed Bagging Active GBP 20 (UK) 3h 12h

docs.title: Vacuum Bagging Carbon - V1 - Enclosed Bagging
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To create a simple, low-cost vacuum environment for small parts using off-the-shelf vacuum storage bags.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Suitable for small to medium parts that fit inside standard vacuum storage bags
  • Maximum part size: limited to the largest bag available
  • Pressure achievable: approximately -0.2 to -0.4 bar with a manual pump
  • Requires a flat, rigid base (e.g. acrylic sheet) to support the part

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• Vacuum storage bags with a compatible manual pump
  • Breather cloth

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Metal file (for smoothing edges of the base or parts)
  • Scissors (for cutting breather cloth)

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Smooth the edges of the base or part using the file to prevent puncturing the vacuum bag.
  2. Place breather cloth around the part to allow airflow inside the bag.
  3. Add an extra layer of breather cloth directly under the vacuum pump connector since this point receives the highest pressure.
  4. Place the entire setup into the vacuum bag.
  5. Seal the bag securely according to the supplier’s instructions.
  6. Use the manual pump to create a vacuum. Stop when the base begins to bend slightly, ensuring enough pressure without risking deformation.
  7. Check the bag after 10 minutes. If the vacuum is lost, the bag may be perforated. Replace the bag and restart the process.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Requires a solid base that can be lifted and inserted into the bag
  • Enclosed vacuum bagging limits the maximum part size to the bag dimensions
  • If the angled part of the acrylic base bends too much under vacuum, the resulting blade might not fit into the foot pocket

docs.title: Vacuum Bagging Carbon - V1 - Edge-Sealed Bagging
docs.text: Research

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To enable vacuum bagging of larger parts by sealing a cut vacuum bag directly to the laminating base using butyl tape, while achieving a controlled and measurable vacuum level.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Suitable for medium to large parts (size limited only by base and bag film availability)
  • Target vacuum level: ~80% vacuum (-0.2 bar relative to atmosphere)
  • Requires a rigid, smooth laminating base for edge sealing

docs.title: Materials / Bill of Materials
docs.text:
• Vacuum bag film cut to size
  • Butyl sealing tape
  • Breather cloth
  • Vacuum gauge
  • Manual vacuum pump

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text:
• Metal roller or rounded tool (for pressing sealant tape firmly)
  • Scissors or utility knife (for cutting bag film and breather cloth)
  • Cleaning cloth and window cleaner

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Clean the edges of the laminating base with a cloth and window cleaner to ensure proper adhesion of the butyl tape.
  2. Cut a sheet of vacuum bag film large enough to cover the part with margin on all sides.
  3. Apply butyl sealing tape along the edges of the laminating base.
  4. Place the vacuum bag film over the base and press it firmly into the butyl tape to create a continuous edge seal.
  5. Install the vacuum pump connector and vacuum gauge through the bag film or at a pre-made port.
  6. Place breather cloth around the part to maintain airflow under the bag.
  7. Start pumping manually and monitor the gauge. Stop when ~80% vacuum (-0.2 bar) is reached.
  8. Check for leaks by observing if the gauge holds steady for at least 10 minutes. If vacuum drops, inspect and reseal edges.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Requires a clean and smooth base surface for proper sealing; dust, grease, or moisture will cause leaks
  • More setup time compared to enclosed bagging
